item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“lare69, post:26, topic:542857”][quote author=jme link=topic=661732.msg4426604#msg4426604 date=1401145258]
especially metal
[/quote]
oh god I hate those fucking girly emo post-hardcore/metalcore bands

The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.

tons of hip hop that was made in 2000-present that is good, you’re generalizing

also people rarely give fuck about the lyrics in gangsta rap lol I don’t even know what dre/snoop are saying in this song, the only reason I like it is because of the production[/quote]Then you are doing it wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

jme:

especially metal

oh god I hate those fucking girly emo post-hardcore/metalcore bands

Elrick:

The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.

tons of hip hop that was made in 2000-present that is good, you’re generalizing

also people rarely give fuck about the lyrics in gangsta rap lol I don’t even know what dre/snoop are saying in this song, the only reason I like it is because of the production

Read full topic
item.source: One of the best rap songs of all time

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Elrick:

The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.

What you consider a lack of creativity, others would find brilliant. The same goes for the music you listen to. And a lot of the bad stuff is just a story or entertainment, like a movie or video game.

If it’s so easy and talentless, why don’t you do it and become rich? Don’t get me wrong, there’s so much rap I think is aweful. Same with any genre especially metal. Certain songs whether simple or complex just resonate with me, it’s really as simple as that.

Read full topic
item.source: One of the best rap songs of all time

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @drubrkletern drubrkletern
item.description:
@drubrkletern wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:20, topic:542857”][quote author=drubrkletern link=topic=661732.msg4425751#msg4425751 date=1400742342]

Did someone really just try to put Dre and Lil B on the same level?
[/quote]its a shame how much people under classify lil b :\

Damnit drub don’t misquote me.[/quote]but i didnt

[quote=“Pure_, post:23, topic:542857”][quote author=Elrick link=topic=661732.msg4425804#msg4425804 date=1400776000]
The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.
[/quote]I’m not going to disagree with you, because to some extent you are correct. But your initial argument, of pioneers being the best because they found the genre is disappointing and foolish at best, which you haven’t addressed adequately IMO (since you’re just generalizing).[/quote]based god perfect counter example

Read full topic

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:22, topic:542857”]The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.[/quote]I’m not going to disagree with you, because to some extent you are correct. But your initial argument, of pioneers being the best because they found the genre is disappointing and foolish at best, which you haven’t addressed adequately IMO (since you’re just generalizing).

Read full topic

The lack of creativity, generic themes, and brutish attempts at portraying rap as a legitimate genre have nearly gone through the windows. Synthesizers, talking lines, and discussing nothing but treating women like property, doing drugs, killing people, and starting from the bottom and being able to make “stacks” with your “crew” is rap as a whole now. I cannot (and will not try to) find the distinct transition of morals and themes in rap, but the old school rappers have a lot more to say in their songs than current rappers. As of lately, rap has nearly turned into pop music with a plethora of curse words and derogatory terms.

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:18, topic:542857”]Did someone really just try to put Pharrell and Dre on the same level?

Although, it really is hard to compare old school rappers versus new school. Old school will always beat out the new purely because they are the founding fathers of the genre.

However, one of the best rappers of all time:
[youtube ]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=otCpCn0l4Wo[/youtube][/quote]Get the fuck outta here, melle mel is a pioneer, does he have skill? NO.

item.title: One of the best rap songs of all time
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Sessy Pk3r, post:11, topic:542857”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=661732.msg4424327#msg4424327 date=1400020039]

Dr. Dre [size=10pt]best producer of all time[/size] in the rap and hip hop industry.

J Dilla? Pharrell? Alchemist? Dre is overrated :3

[/quote][size=10pt]J Dilla is dead.[/size] Pharrell is just coming out [of the closet] and the Alchemist is actually decent.

http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2012/02/questlove-on-why-dilla-was-the-best-rap-producer-of-all-time/[/quote]In my opinion he never got a lot of good work done so it’s hard to say he’s anything near the best (just because someone releases one amazing track, does that make them the GOAT?). That aside, implying XXLMag, let alone the guy called questlove’s opinion means anything.

Read full topic

Dr. Dre best producer of all time in the rap and hip hop industry.
[/quote]

Nas, Tupac, Eminem?[/quote]They aren’t solely producers (on and off, but it’s not their day job like Dre, fun fact: dre generally has his stuff ghost written).

I do enjoy some of Dre’s beats but in my opinion he has fallen off.
